content:
What Operating System are you using ? What version of Thunderbird are you using ?

If Thunderbird crashed then there should be a crash id. But that would mean you just restart Thunderbird to see emails. OR do you mean Thunderbird freezes, so you have to use the 'Task Manager' to force it to quit ?

Either way you would never need to restart the computer. Is your computer crashing ?

Please post info:

  • Menu icon > Help > More TRoublshooting Information
  • Scroll down to crash reports section.
  • You should see some crash id's. They typically start with a bp-then a load of numbers and letters.
  • Copy the crash ids and paste them in this forum question.


Please check your computer has it's graphic drivers all up to date.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Please confirm the exact method you perform to get a crash.

Do you click on 'Write' and thunderbird immediately crashes?

Or are you able to click on 'Write', but it crashes when you try to add a 'TO' email address or are you trying to use a 'Bcc' email address?

OR you can click on Write and enter email address in TO, Cc or Bcc, but when you try to type in the body content area then it crashes.

I need some very specific instructions on what you do when you get a crash.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :I then moved it deliberately (up one level so that it was no longer a subfolder) using drag and drop and it disappeared.

When you move it up one level, you are moving it out of the folder and putting it into the mail account as a top level folder - so that means you would have dropped it into the 'account name' folder. Did you drop it into the 'mail account' name folder ? If no then you removed it - you dropped it into no-where land... so maybe you need to subscribe to see it. You say it is on the server so you should be able to subcribe to see it.

Suggest you try this:

  • Right click on mail account name folder in Folder Pane and select 'Subscribe'
  • click on 'Refresh'
  • select the folder
  • click on Subscribe'
  • Click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thunderbird profile data is stored in appdata, a hidden windows folder. It is not backed up or specifically saved when a windows reinstall occurs, although this hidden folder is sometime saved in a windows.old folder on the hard disk.

It will be difficult to access unless you know about the file system and are comfortable working with it even if it is saved. Personally I recommend you proceed as if the data will be erased and make appropriate backups before you risk loosing everything.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Harridu said
How can I tell thunderbird on Linux to create and use global-messages-db.sqlite in an arbitrary directory, eg /dev/shm instead of slow NFS storage?

You can't. It is not a user option.

I know it will be gone on the next reboot, but that doesn't matter to me.

Disable global search will probably see you have no global DB, but it's location is not user configurable.

content:
I filed a bug report some 12 months ago on the topic. Fundamentally the account settings for some accounts simply are not listed at times.

Bug reports for primarily SMTP servers. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1788978 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1773123 https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1731518

This bug 1773123 is marked as fixed in 104, but all of that is about SMTP servers, so perhaps a copmment in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1788978 would be appropriate.

content:
You say " I have checked settings and they are correct."

So I'm asuming you have this set up:

  • Outgoing server name: mail.twc.com
  • port 587
  • Connection security = None
  • authentication = password, transmitted insecurely
  • User name = full email address.

OR are you using same as above with two modifications:

  • Connection security = STARTTLS
  • authentication Method = normal password

Please note the 'User Name' does need to be the same email address as used for the pop account.

But, I'm not sure what your Outgoing Server (SMTP) settings have been set up to use.

Please post some information showing exactly what you are using to stop all the guessing OR change your settings to what I've mentioned above, then exit Thunderbird, wait a short while and then start Thunderbird.


  • Menu > Help > More TRoubleshooting Information
  • Scroll to 'Mail and News Accounts'
  • Copy all the data and post it into this forum.
  • Access 'Account Settings'
  • In left pane scroll to bottom
  • click on 'Outgoing Server SMTP
  • select the smtp in the list
  • post an image showing the settings
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Did you recently Logon to the webmail account and change your password?

If yes, did you update the stored password in Thunderbird ?

  • Menu icon > Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords
  • click on 'Show Passwords'

You will have two lines for the account.

  1. one is mailbox:// server name
  2. one is smtp://server name
  • Right click on the smtp line and select 'Edit Password'
  • completely remove all contents and then carefully type in the correct password
  • click on 'Close'

Exit Thunderbird, wait a few moments and then start Thunderbird to ensure it is using the correct data.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: The default is off. The settings for this are stored is a session.json file in the profile folder and historically most folk who have issues with the toolbar reverting to default also have ccleaner deleting the storage file "for your security" or some such.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I don't use Ccleaner. That the default is "OFF" is irrelevant! I set it to ON, and for whatever reason, Thunderbird flips it at random. That's a bug, and it needs fixing!

(ps 25 years in IT, I know what I'm talking about ;-> )

Cheers Jeremy
creator: jeremypoynton

content:
Just because it randomly switches off does not necessarilly mean it's a bug. If it were a bug usually it means several people would be reporting the problem and no other reason was effecting the cause. That is not occuring.

Matt's info is really useful. It's not just CCleaner or other similar products like WiseCleaner that can cause an issue with a session file, there are plenty of Anti-Virus products that can also cause a problem if they are allowed to scan profile folders or clean up session files. I've often come across this as a problem.

Another reason for it occuring: I have come across people who report same issue -Quick Filter Bar keeps randomly switching off - only to discover they were unknowingly switching it off. This is usually more likely to occur if you are someone who is familiar with using the keyboard which I'm assuming you may do since you've been in IT for a while.

  • The keyboard 'Esc' key is the shortcut to switch it off.
  • The keyboard 'Shift'+ 'Ctrl' + 'K' will switch it on.

Is it possible you have unknowingly been using the shortcut key that auto switches it off ?

It would help if you tell us how you switch it on. As you may be aware, there are various methods designed to suit personal needs. Then we can check to see if the method you use has been reported as having a problem. Do you normally use the keyboard or mouse click method ? Do you use the 'Quick Filter' button on the 'Mail Toolbar' to enable/disable the Quick Filter Bar ? Do you use the shortcut keys as mentioned above? Do you use the 'Menu Bar' toolbar ? - eg: 'Alt' + V then T and then Q ? Do you use the 'Menu icon' the 'View' > 'Toolbars' > select 'Quick Filter Bar' ?
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: jeremypoynton

content:
Please provide responses to all the other information I asked. I'm not sitting next to you and I'm not a mind reader, so I do not know what processes you use.

I'm not sure what level or experience you have in all the various areas that IT can mean or what you have been involved with for all I know you could have just been using MS Office but either way I'm sure you understand why the information is required.

I agree, it should be only you who chooses what occurs, but at this point, it's possible it is you or the computer AV etc. That's why we need information.

You mention you are using Windows Defender and Malwarebytes. Are you saying you allow your thunderbird profile folders and all files therein to get scanned by these products ? Have you got them set up to auto fix files or just quarrantine them or ask you what to do with files these products do not like ? Never allow these products to auto fix any thunderbird file or folder, always force it to ask what to do. If it is set to quantine then is anything in the quarrantine folder?

OR Is your Thunderbird profile folder exempt from allowing any scanning access by Windows Defender and Malwarebytes ?


Basically, it sounds like you have stated - you are running software that can remove suspicious files, temporary files, session files etc and you are allowing them access to files in the Thunderbird profile.

If this is true then make the Thunderbird profile folders exempt from access by both Defender and Malwarebytes. You have to be certain these programs are not messing around in Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Per la questione 1) Il servizio email utilizzato da un mittente permette di solito di personalizzare il campo "nome del mittente" per cui un indirizzo alfa@example.com potrebbe in teoria mettere come nome beta@altro.example.org con un risultato simile a quello che mostri nelle immagini. Per capire se √® questo il caso o se effettivamente c'√® un problema in Thunderbird occorerebbe analizzare il sorgente del messaggio (Ctrl + U) -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/scorciatoie-da-tastiera-di-thunderbird#w_azioni-sui-messaggi

Nel caso il problema fosse effettivamente di Thunderbird, generalmente avrebbe origine da un disallineamento tra l'indice e gli archivi e si risolve in tre passi:

  • backup -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo
  • compattazione delle cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle
  • ricostruzione dell'indice -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale

Per la questione 2) La ricerca avviene per parole intere. Se cos√¨ non fosse, cercando "per" verrebbero fuori tutte le mail che contengono pera, per√≤, Per√π, peraltro, perno, etc. Cosa che nella maggior parte dei casi sarebbe errata. Poi ci sta che nel tuo caso magari sarebbe preferibile il contrario ma non si possono coprire contemporaneamente esigenze incompatibili

content:
There are no less than 13 Gmail accounts. Do all accounts are affected, or just a particular one? In the latter case, which is the troubled one?

As per the Troubleshooting Information, account17 somehow sticks out. It does use different SMTP settings than the other 12 accounts. Is account17 the troubled one?
creator: christ1

content:
Every time I open Thunderbird email, "Add Security Exception" pops up.

The server cert has expired, hence the exception prompt. It needs to be renewed.

Should I confirm the exception ... ?

That's your decision. If you think you're connected to a legitimate server you can probably create the exception.

how do I fix this?

See above.
creator: christ1

content:
first make sure ESET is not monitoring your Thunderbird profile folder. You press delete, the file is updated, Eset scans the file, you click delete and repeat, but that sequence might be falling over itself. EST is not known for it's speed. I dropped it in favor of defender 2 years ago because is had become a slug.

So old school time.

Windopws has some useful shortcuts. I have been using that since the early 1990s. List can be controled with both the mouse and the keyboard.

Ctrl+A selected everything in a list. 50,000 emails in a list. Not an issue. After you select something, holding the shift key allows ever everything between the selected item and where you click next to be selected. The next adjunct to that is holding the Ctrl key while clicking. This reverses the selection status of only the list item clicked. Using these techniques together can allow for huge list with many personalizations to select or unselect items to be managed. In this case with a press of the delete key to get all selected items deleted.

You could also use the little widget above the up down slider to customise the list headings to include "select messages" that puts a web page style select box beside each entry. Apparently introduced for "accessibility" but personally I think it is to cater for a community of folk that only know how to use web pages, but are actually not familiar with the use of a keyboard.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Please look at the bottom row of the Thunderbird screen, as that is where it displays.
creator: davidsk

content: You might look in the system temp folder at a left over tmp file from around the same time and date (open them in notepad) but that is about it.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
You can create a filter and delete them automatically. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/organize-your-messages-using-filters

Note, the attempt to fight typical spam messages using static filters is futile.

content: You picture shows the Write window for plain text messages, which omits the formatting toolbar. Switch the default to HTML format in Account Settings, or hold Shift when clicking Write, Reply or Forward.

content:
I think we're dealing with two separate issues here.

1. some sort of data loss following mail file corruption

When accumulating messages in Inbox anti-virus software takes a lot longer to scan a large Inbox file. During scanning the file is blocked for Thunderbird, often leading to 'Not responding' situations. It can also cause mail file corruption, which then can cause data loss. This is possibly what happened in your case.

I don't think you can recover any lost messages unless you do have a backup of your Thunderbird profile created prior to the incident.

These are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

For example, my "drafts" folder currently says it contains 839,028 KB and there is not one draft in that folder.

You need to allow Thunderbird to either automatically compact folders, or manually trigger compacting. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/compacting-folders

2. duplicate messages in Inbox

This may be due to a corrupted popstate.dat file. Try to delete popstate.dat. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Popstate.dat

content: My apologies to all, especially Christ1, whose efforts and responses are very much appreciated, for the long delay in addressing this problem further. Life distractions forced me to simply live with this problem, until this week when I was able to give it attention again. I did delete the popstate.dat file, which seemed to immediately re-generate itself. Not sure whether that was supposed to happen, but it did not solve the problem. I discovered that duplicate messages began to appear on the server as well and I got through to their support department, which discovered the source of the problem rather quickly and resolved it on their end. I'm embarrassed that it turned out not to be a TB issue, but the duplication of messages didn't show up on the server until now. At any rate, thank you to the support community for all its efforts in my behalf. Joe Rogul
creator: CWTL
